subject: Re: [junit] About the value of JUnit
msgSnippet: ... I have used JTest as well as a host of similar tools and I do not consider it a substitute. Using JTest is in the same category as turning up the warning
messageBody:
On Thursday, April 3, 2003, at 08:56 PM, David Vydra wrote:

> I will confess to be partial, but from what I've seen TDD/JUnit will
> make
> you very productive if you can develop the disciple needed to use this
> approach. I have not used JTest, but I do not see it as a substitute.
>
I have used JTest as well as a host of similar tools and I do not
consider it a substitute. Using JTest is in the same category as
turning up the warning level on your compiler all the way. It allows
you to flag "unsafe" constructs and finds things which are likely to be
errors, but no automated tool can judge intention, so they cannot find
real design errors. Unit Testing does not find these errors either per
se, but the *process* of Unit Testing and TDD uncovers them. Take the
following piece of (pseudo) code:

/**
* @post return = x * i
*/
public int f(int x, int i)
{
return x * i;
}

Is this code right? Who knows? What is it *supposed* to do? No
automated tool can tell you that the return value should actually
contain the *sum* of x and i. The only way to figure that out is to try
to use the code in a unit test and realize you cannot connect the
pieces you wish to connect or that you are getting the wrong answer.

A tool can generate "automated" test cases for the above, and those
tools will generate data to test the post-condition. Of course both the
code *and* the postcondition are wrong. They often will be because they
are cut and pasted from the code. In many cases, the postcondition
cannot be expressed any more succinctly than the code itself.

A tool cannot automate testing because a tool does not have access to
the human context in which the code makes sense (or fails to). Unit
testing tends to uncover these errors in profusion. Often it is not
even that test cases fail but that the errors are noticed when the test
cases are being written and a serious mistake is uncovered. Test-First
Design makes this process more efficient by preventing the faulty code
from being written in the first place.

One of the largest advantages of TDD, therefore, is the switch in
focus, from inside to outside. Writing the test cases forces one to
look at the code being written from the point of view of the caller and
notice errors which are not apparent from the narrow context of the
code itself. Automated tools do not facilitate this thought because
their stated purpose is to remove the need to think about the issues.
Their only context is internal. And so, the issues are not thought
about and the coding happily continues right off a cliff.

Automated tools are useful, but they do not replace discipline and
process.
